trial_identification.studytitle: The effectiveness of functional motor control exercise training in patients with chronic low back pain
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effectiveness of functional motor control exercise training versus general exercise on movement control ability, pain intensity, disability in patients with chronic low back pain

interventions.interventions: Functional motor control exercise including core muscle strengthening, spine segmental control, trunk and extremity dissociated movement control retraining will be administered by a physiotherapist. Participants in this group will receive 16 one-to-one sessions (45 minutes/session), twice a week for 8 weeks. The exercise programs will be tailored to individual patient. Outcome will be assessed upon completion of the 8-week program and at 6-week follow-up after the treatment.
interventions.comparator: General exercise will include trunk and extremity strengthening, stretching exercises. Each patient will receive at least 10 sessions (30 minutes/session) of treatment in 8 weeks. The program will be one-to-one sessions with a physiotherapist. The maximum number of sessions that may be administered is 16.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Movement control ability assessed by a battery of movement control tests including 7 flexion control tests and 7 extension control tests
primaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, upon completion of 8-week training, 6-week follow-up

primaryOutcome.outcome: Psychological impairment: Fear avoidance beliefs questionnaire (FABQ)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, upon completion of 8-week training, 6-week follow-up

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, upon completion of 8-week training, 6-week follow-up

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Disability: Oswestry low back pain disability questionnaire
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, upon completion of 8-week training, 6-week follow-up

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Movement confidence: Low back activity confidence scale (LoBACS)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, upon completion of 8-week training, 6-week follow-up

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Perceived improvement: Global rating of change scale (GRoCS)

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: baseline, upon completion of 8-week training, 6-week follow-up
baseline, upon completion of 8-week training, 6-week follow-up

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: 1. Aged 20-65 patients with chronic low back pain (more than 3 months) 2. Pain intensity (numeric rating scale) > 4/10 3. No lower extremity symptoms
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Tumor 2. Spinal/lower extremity surgery 3. Osteoporosis 4. Hip/knee osteoarthritis 5. Pregnancy 6. Experiencing any of the spinal inflammatory diseases (such as ankylosing spondylitis, rheumatoid arthritis)

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: 155, Sec. 2, Li-Nong St. Beitou District, Taipei 11221

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Our study purpose is to compare the improvement of movement control ability and clinical outcomes in patients with chronic low back pain after functional motor control exercise training.
Our hypothesis is that patients in the functional motor control exercise group will demonstrate better improvement of movement control ability and clinical outcomes than those in the general exercise group.
